A Theoretical Framework for Grokking: Interpolation followed by Riemannian Norm Minimisation

Etienne Boursier
INRIA
LMO, UniversitÃ© Paris-Saclay
Orsay, France
etienne.boursier@inria.fr
&Scott Pesme
INRIA
Grenoble, France
scott.pesme@inria.fr
&Radu-Alexandru Dragomir
TÃ©lÃ©com Paris
Institut Polytechnique de Paris
Palaiseau, France
dragomir@telecom-paris.fr
Abstract

We study the dynamics of gradient flow with small weight decay on general training losses F:â„dâ†’â„:ğ¹â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„F:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R. Under mild regularity assumptions and assuming convergence of the unregularised gradient flow, we show that the trajectory with weight decayÂ Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» exhibits a two-phase behaviour as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0. During the initial fast phase, the trajectory follows the unregularised gradient flow and converges to a manifold of critical points of Fğ¹Fitalic_F. Then, at time of order 1/Î»1ğœ†1/\lambda1 / italic_Î», the trajectory enters a slow drift phase and follows a Riemannian gradient flow minimising the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the parameters. This purely optimisation-based phenomenon offers a natural explanation for the grokking effect observed in deep learning, where the training loss rapidly reaches zero while the test loss plateaus for an extended period before suddenly improving. We argue that this generalisation jump can be attributed to the slow norm reduction induced by weight decay, as explained by our analysis. We validate this mechanism empirically on several synthetic regression tasks.

1 Introduction

Strikingly simple algorithms such as gradient methods are a driving force behind the success of deep learning. Nonetheless, their remarkable performance remains mysterious, and a full theoretical understanding is lacking. In particular: (i) convergence to low training loss solutions on non-convex objectives is far from trivial, and (ii) it is unclear why the resulting solutions generalise wellÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2017). These questions are accompanied by a range of surprising phenomena that arise during training. One such intriguing behaviour is known as the grokking phenomenon, which we explore in this work. Coined byÂ Power etÂ al. (2022), this term describes a two-phase pattern in the learning curves: first, the training loss rapidly decreases to zero, while the test loss plateaus at a certain value. This is followed by a second phase, where the training loss remains zero, but the test loss steadily decreases, leading to a final improved generalisation performance, as depicted inÂ FigureÂ 1 (left).

In this paper, we propose a novel theoretical perspective to explain this phenomenon. By examining the gradient flow dynamics with weight decay, we show that, in the limit of vanishing weight decay, we can fully describe the trajectory of the model parameters. Specifically, we prove that the training process can be decomposed into two distinct phases. In the first phase, the gradient flow follows the unregularised path, converging to a manifold of critical points of the training loss. In the second, the trajectory enters a slow drift phase, where the weights move along this manifold, driven by weight decay, gradually reducing their â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, as illustrated inÂ FigureÂ 1 (right). We argue that this slow decrease in the weight norms explains the grokking phenomenon, as smaller weight norms are often correlated with better generalisation. To convey the main intuition, we state below an informal version of our result, describing the full trajectory of the gradient flow with small weight decay.

Informal statement of the result.

For a generic training loss F:â„dâ†’â„:ğ¹â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„F:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R satisfying some regularity assumptions, we consider the gradient flow wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT regularised with weight decay: wË™Î»â¢(t)=âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ¢(wÎ»â¢(t))âˆ’Î»â¢wÎ»â¢(t)superscriptË™ğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡\dot{w}^{\lambda}(t)=-\nabla F(w^{\lambda}(t))-\lambda w^{\lambda}(t)overË™ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - âˆ‡ italic_F ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) - italic_Î» italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ). Under the assumption that the unregularised gradient flow trajectory is bounded, we prove the following.

Theorem 1 (Main result, informal).

As the weight decay parameter Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» is taken to 00, the trajectory wÎ»â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡w^{\lambda}(t)italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) can be seen as a composition of two coupled dynamics:

  1. 1.

    (Fast dynamics driven by F given by PropositionÂ 1) In a first phase, the weights follow the unregularised gradient flow and converge to a manifold of critical points of Fğ¹Fitalic_F.

  2. 2.

    (Slow dynamics driven by the weight decay given by PropositionÂ 2) At time tâ‰ˆ1/Î»ğ‘¡1ğœ†t\approx 1/\lambdaitalic_t â‰ˆ 1 / italic_Î», the iterates start slowly drifting along this manifold, following a Riemannian gradient flow that decreases the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the weights.

Link with the grokking phenomenon.

Note this is a purely optimisation result: no statistical assumptions are made, and it a priori does not imply any improvement in test loss during the slow phase. However, it provides a natural explanation for the grokking phenomenon. Indeed, in practice, for many deep learning models with random initialisation, gradient flow converges to a global minimiser of the training loss. When this solution generalises poorlyâ€”as is often the case with large initial weights, in the so-called lazy regime (Chizat etÂ al., 2019)â€”the subsequent slow drift along the critical manifold, driven by weight decay, decreases the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the solution and simplifies it in the second phase. Since lower weight norms often correlate with better generalisationÂ (Bach, 2017; Liu etÂ al., 2022c; Dâ€™Angelo etÂ al., 2024), this offers a convincing explanation for the delayed improvement in test performance. We discuss various settings where this behaviour is observed inÂ SectionÂ 5.

2 Related work

Grokking in experimental works.

The term grokking was originally coined by Power etÂ al. (2022), which studied a two-layer transformer trained with weight decay on a modular addition task. They observed that the network quickly fits the training data while generalising poorly, followed much later by a sudden transition to near-perfect generalisation. Following this work, many studies have investigated modular addition tasks to better understand the mechanisms underlying this phenomenonÂ (Nanda etÂ al., 2023; Gromov, 2023). However, grokking has been observed far beyond this setting. For instance, Barak etÂ al. (2022) showed that training a neural network to learn parities exhibits a similar delayed generalisation pattern. In Liu etÂ al. (2022c), grokking was induced across a broad range of tasks, including image classification and sentiment analysis, by using small datasets, large initialisations, and weight decay. Other settings and architectures where grokking-like behaviour appears include matrix factorisationÂ (Lyu etÂ al., 2023) and learning XOR-clustered data with a ReLU networkÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2023). Finally, it is worth noting that this delayed transition in generalisation was already observed in earlier works, as clearly illustrated in Figure 3 of Chizat and Bach (2020).

Grokking as the transition between lazy and rich regimes.

Several works have framed grokking as the transition between the lazy and rich regimes. The lazy regime, also called the NTK regime, was introduced by Jacot etÂ al. (2018). It typically arises when the network is trained from large initialisationsÂ (Chizat etÂ al., 2019), and corresponds to a setting where zero training loss can be quickly achieved, but often with poor generalisation performance. In contrast, the rich regime (also called the feature learning regime) corresponds to a setting where the network actively learns new internal features during training. In the classification setting, Lyu and Li (2019) show that the rich regime is always attained for homogeneous parameterisations, and similarly, Chizat and Bach (2020) provide an analogous result for infinitely wide two-layer networks. In this context, Lyu etÂ al. (2023) and Kumar etÂ al. (2024), followed by Mohamadi etÂ al. (2024), offer a theoretical perspective on grokking as the transition from the lazy regime to the rich regime during training: initially, the predictor quickly converges towards the NTK solution, and later escapes this regime to reach a better generalising solution, driven by the effects of implicit regularisation and/or weight decay.

The role of weight decay.

The role of weight decay in grokking remains somewhat debated. While many of the original works exhibiting the phenomenon include weight decayÂ (Power etÂ al., 2022; Liu etÂ al., 2022b), grokking has also been observed withoutÂ (Chizat and Bach, 2020; Xu etÂ al., 2023), as strongly emphasised by Kumar etÂ al. (2024). However, as shown inÂ Lyu etÂ al. (2023), the transition tends to occur much later and to be less sharp without weight decay. In this context, weight decay can be interpreted as a factor that triggers or accelerates the transition from the lazy to the rich regime. While grokking can be observed in classification tasks even without weight decayâ€”thanks to the algorithmâ€™s implicit biasâ€”to the best of our knowledge, it cannot occur in regression tasks unless weight decay is used. Of particular relevance to our work, Liu etÂ al. (2022c) propose an intuitive explanation of grokking that is based on weight decay: during the first phase, the model rapidly converges to a poor global minimum; during the second, slower phase, weight decay gradually steers the iterates toward a lower-norm solution with better generalisation properties. While appealing, this explanation remains informal and lacks rigorous theoretical support. In this work, we provide a formal analysis of the optimisation dynamics underlying the grokking phenomenon: an initial fast phase leads to convergence toward the solution associated with the lazy regime, followed by a slower second phase that drives convergence toward the solution characteristic of the rich regime.

Drift on the interpolation manifold.

Many theoretical works in the machine learning community have studied the training dynamics of gradient methods in overparameterised neural networks, where the set of zero training loss solutions forms a high-dimensional manifold. In this context, leveraging results from dynamical systems theoryÂ (Katzenberger, 1990), the work of Li etÂ al. (2021) describes the drift dynamics induced by stochastic noise after stochastic gradient descent (SGD) reaches the manifold. This analysis was further extended by Shalova etÂ al. (2024). Leveraging a similar stochastic differential framework, Vivien etÂ al. (2022) precisely characterises this drift in the setting of diagonal linear networks, and proves that it leads to desirable sparsity guarantees. Much in the spirit of our work, although outside the deep learning context, Fatkullin etÂ al. (2010) derive stochastic differential equations that describe the dynamics of systems with small random perturbations on energy landscapes with manifolds of minima, illustrating how the system first converges to the manifold and then drifts along it. Whereas these works emphasise drift induced by the stochasticity of gradient updates, our analysis focuses on a deterministic drift arising from the regularisation of the training objective.

3 Setting and preliminaries

We consider a loss function F:â„dâ†’â„+:ğ¹â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptâ„F:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_F : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which is sufficiently smooth, as stated in AssumptionÂ 1 below. Typical examples include the least square loss over some training dataset, where the parameters to optimise represent the weights of some neural network architecture. For a given Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0, we define the regularised loss FÎ»subscriptğ¹ğœ†F_{\lambda}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as:

FÎ»â¢(w)â‰”Fâ¢(w)+Î»2â¢â€–wâ€–22,âˆ€wâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequenceâ‰”subscriptğ¹ğœ†ğ‘¤ğ¹ğ‘¤ğœ†2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¤22for-allğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\displaystyle F_{\lambda}(w)\coloneqq F(w)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w\|_{2}^{2},% \qquad\forall w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) â‰” italic_F ( italic_w ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_w âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Initialising the parameters from w0âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘¤0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (independently of Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»), we then consider the gradient flow wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over the regularised loss for any Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0, as the solution of the differential equation

wË™Î»â¢(t)=âˆ’âˆ‡FÎ»â¢(wÎ»â¢(t))Â andÂ wÎ»â¢(0)=w0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptË™ğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡Â andÂ superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†0subscriptğ‘¤0\begin{gathered}\dot{w}^{\lambda}(t)=-\nabla F_{\lambda}(w^{\lambda}(t))\quad% \text{ and }\quad w^{\lambda}(0)=w_{0}.\end{gathered}start_ROW start_CELL overË™ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (1)

Gradient flow is the limit dynamics of (stochastic) gradient descent as the learning rate goes to 0. For Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0italic_Î» = 0, we denote wGFsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the gradient flow on the unregularised loss:

wË™GFâ¢(t)=âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ¢(wGFâ¢(t))Â andÂ wGFâ¢(0)=w0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptË™ğ‘¤GFğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ‘¤GFğ‘¡Â andÂ superscriptğ‘¤GF0subscriptğ‘¤0\begin{gathered}\dot{w}^{\mathrm{GF}}(t)=-\nabla F(w^{\mathrm{GF}}(t))\quad% \text{ and }\quad w^{\mathrm{GF}}(0)=w_{0}.\end{gathered}start_ROW start_CELL overË™ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - âˆ‡ italic_F ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (2)

In the remaining of the paper, we consider the following assumption on the objective function.

Assumption 1.

The function Fğ¹Fitalic_F is ğ’3superscriptğ’3\mathcal{C}^{3}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, its third derivative is locally Lipschitz and Fğ¹Fitalic_F is definable in an o-minimal structure. Moreover, the solution wGFsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the gradient flow ODE (2) is bounded.

The regularity conditions on Fğ¹Fitalic_F ensure that, for any Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0italic_Î» â‰¥ 0, the gradient flow ODE has a unique solution, which is defined for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0. This is a consequence of the Picardâ€“LindelÃ¶f theorem and boundedness of the trajectories. Definability in the o-minimal sense guarantees that bounded gradient flow trajectories converge to a limit pointÂ (Kurdyka, 1998, Thm. 2). This is a mild assumption satisfied by most functions arising in applications, such as polynomials, logarithms, exponentials, subanalytic functions, and finite combinations of those; see Coste (1999); Bolte etÂ al. (2007) for more details. Finally, note that the boundedness assumption on the unregularised flow excludes classification settings where the network can perfectly separate the data, since in such cases the unregularised iterates diverge.

3.1 Stationary manifold and Riemannian flow

AssumptionÂ 1 guarantees that the gradient flow converges to a limit point wâˆGFâ‰”limtâ†’âˆwGFâ¢(t)â‰”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤GFsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤GFğ‘¡w^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}\coloneqq\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\mathrm{GF}}(t)italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ), which is a stationary point of Fğ¹Fitalic_F. In typical scenarios of training overparameterised models, stationary points are not isolated, but form continuous sets (Cooper, 2021).

Definition (Definition of the manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M).

We define â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M to be the largest connected component of âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) containingÂ wâˆGFsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) corresponds to the set of stationary points of Fğ¹Fitalic_F.

Our key assumption is that â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M forms a smooth manifold, and that it contains only local minimizers (and not saddle points). Additionnally, we impose that the non-zero eigenvalues of the Hessian on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M are lower bounded by some constant Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0italic_Î· > 0. Following the terminology of Rebjock and Boumal (2024), this is known as the Morse-Bott property.

Assumption 2.

â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is a smooth submanifold of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of dimension kâˆˆ[d]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘‘k\in[d]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_d ], i.e. for any wâˆˆâ„³ğ‘¤â„³w\in\mathcal{M}italic_w âˆˆ caligraphic_M, rankâ¢(âˆ‡2Fâ¢(w))=dâˆ’kranksuperscriptâˆ‡2ğ¹ğ‘¤ğ‘‘ğ‘˜\mathrm{rank}(\nabla^{2}F(w))=d-kroman_rank ( âˆ‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) ) = italic_d - italic_k. Also, there exists Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0italic_Î· > 0 such that for any wâˆˆâ„³ğ‘¤â„³w\in\mathcal{M}italic_w âˆˆ caligraphic_M, all non-zero eigenvalues of âˆ‡2Fâ¢(w)superscriptâˆ‡2ğ¹ğ‘¤\nabla^{2}F(w)âˆ‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) are lower bounded by Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·.

As stated in Rebjock and Boumal (2024), for ğ’2superscriptğ’2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT functions this property is equivalent to the Kurdykaâ€“Åojasiewicz, also known as Polyakâ€“Åojasiewicz (PL) condition locally aroundÂ â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M (Kurdyka, 1998; Bolte etÂ al., 2009). It implies that (i) every point in â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is a local minimiser, and (ii) all gradient flow trajectories are locally attracted towards â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M. This stability property is essential for proving regularity of the flow map Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ in SectionÂ 4. Let us discuss the relevance of AssumptionÂ 2 in the context of overparameterised machine learning.

  • â€¢

    Convergence to a local minimiser: our assumption rules out the possibility that wGFsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to a saddle point of Fğ¹Fitalic_F. This is justified by a large number of works showing that gradient methods avoid saddle points for almost all initialisations. In particular, Lee etÂ al. (2016, 2019) prove it under the assumption that all saddle points of Fğ¹Fitalic_F are strict. Although their result only holds for discrete-time gradient descent, the underlying argument can be extended to gradient flow (the proof relies on the Stable Manifold Theorem for dynamical systems, which also holds in continuous time (Teschl, 2012, Â§7)).

  • â€¢

    Morse-Bott/Åojasiewicz property: this is a common assumption in the analysis of gradient flow dynamics for overparameterised networks (Li etÂ al., 2021; Fatkullin etÂ al., 2010; Shalova etÂ al., 2024). Note that for general models, the critical set may not form a manifold everywhere. However, it is often possible to show that the manifold structure holds on most of the space, excluding some degenerate points; see SectionÂ 5 for examples and Liu etÂ al. (2022a) for a generic result. Moreover, the results derived from such an assumption are generally very representative of empirical observations, as can be seen in SectionÂ 5.

Riemannian gradient flow on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M.

We endow â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M with the standard Euclidean metric. For any differentiable function h:â„dâ†’â„:â„â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„h:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R, we denote by gradâ„³â¢hsubscriptgradâ„³â„\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}hroman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h the Riemannian gradient on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M of the function hâ„hitalic_h defined as follows:

gradâ„³â¢h:â„³â†’â„dwâ†¦PTâ„³â¢(w)â¢(âˆ‡hâ¢(w)),:subscriptgradâ„³â„â†’â„³superscriptâ„ğ‘‘maps-toğ‘¤subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡â„³ğ‘¤âˆ‡â„ğ‘¤\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}h:\begin{array}[]{l}\mathcal{M}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}\\ w\mapsto P_{T_{\mathcal{M}}(w)}(\nabla h(w)),\end{array}roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h : start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_M â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_w â†¦ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( âˆ‡ italic_h ( italic_w ) ) , end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

where PTâ„³â¢(w)subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡â„³ğ‘¤P_{T_{\mathcal{M}}(w)}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the orthogonal projection on the tangent space to â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M at wğ‘¤witalic_w. Under AssumptionÂ 2, typical properties of smooth manifolds imply that Tâ„³â¢(w)=Kerâ¢(âˆ‡2Fâ¢(w))subscriptğ‘‡â„³ğ‘¤Kersuperscriptâˆ‡2ğ¹ğ‘¤T_{\mathcal{M}}(w)=\mathrm{Ker}(\nabla^{2}F(w))italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) = roman_Ker ( âˆ‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) ) (see e.g., Boumal, 2023, for a detailed introduction to optimisation on manifolds). Using this notion of Riemannian gradient, we study the Riemannian gradient flow for some objective function hâ„hitalic_h and initialization wâ„³âˆˆâ„³subscriptğ‘¤â„³â„³w_{\mathcal{M}}\in\mathcal{M}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_M, defined as the curve wğ‘¤witalic_w satisfying,

wË™â¢(t)=âˆ’gradâ„³â¢hâ¢(wâ¢(t))Â andÂ wâ¢(0)=wâ„³.formulae-sequenceË™ğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptgradâ„³â„ğ‘¤ğ‘¡Â andÂ ğ‘¤0subscriptğ‘¤â„³\dot{w}(t)=-\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}h(w(t))\quad\text{ and }\quad w(0)=w_{% \mathcal{M}}.overË™ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG ( italic_t ) = - roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_w ( italic_t ) ) and italic_w ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (3)

By construction of the Riemannian gradient, the trajectory of any solution of this ODE necessarily belongs to âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ), and therefore to â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, since â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is a maximal connected component. If hâ„hitalic_h is ğ’2superscriptğ’2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and has compact sublevel sets, Assumptions 1 and 2 guarantee that there exists a unique solution to EquationÂ 3 and that it is defined on â„+subscriptâ„\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

4 Grokking as two-timescale dynamics

This section states our main results, where we characterise the two-timescale dynamics of the regularised gradient flow (1) in the limit Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0. In SectionÂ 4.1 we describe the first phase, the fast dynamics, where wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT approximates the unregularised gradient flow solution on finite time horizons. SectionÂ 4.2 then identifies the second, slow dynamics happening at arbitrarily large time horizons, where wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT follows the Riemannian flow of the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm on the manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M of stationary points.

4.1 Fast dynamics

A first simple observation is that as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0, FÎ»â†’Fâ†’subscriptğ¹ğœ†ğ¹F_{\lambda}\to Fitalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_F uniformly on any compact of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. From there, it seems natural that wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should converge, at least pointwise, to wGFsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0. A GrÃ¶nwall argument indeed allows to characterise the first, fast timescale dynamics given by PropositionÂ 1 below.

Proposition 1.

If AssumptionÂ 1 holds, then for all Tâ‰¥0ğ‘‡0T\geq 0italic_T â‰¥ 0, wÎ»â¢âŸ¶Î»â†’0â¢wGâ¢Fsuperscriptğ‘¤ğœ†â†’ğœ†0âŸ¶superscriptğ‘¤ğºğ¹w^{\lambda}\underset{\lambda\to 0}{\longrightarrow}w^{GF}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG âŸ¶ end_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_G italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (ğ’0([0,T],â„d),âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)(\mathcal{C}^{0}([0,T],\mathbb{R}^{d}),\|\cdot\|_{\infty})( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , italic_T ] , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

Importantly, uniform convergence only holds on finite time intervals of the form [0,T]0ğ‘‡[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ], but is not true on â„+subscriptâ„\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. More precisely, grokking is observed when the two limits cannot be exchanged: limÎ»â†’0+limtâ†’âˆwÎ»â¢(t)â‰ limtâ†’âˆlimÎ»â†’0+wÎ»â¢(t)=limtâ†’âˆwGFâ¢(t)subscriptâ†’ğœ†superscript0subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscriptâ†’ğœ†superscript0superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤GFğ‘¡\lim_{\lambda\to 0^{+}}\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda}(t)\neq\lim_{t\to\infty}% \lim_{\lambda\to 0^{+}}w^{\lambda}(t)=\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\mathrm{GF}}(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) â‰  roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ). In FigureÂ 1, the endpoint of the red arrow corresponds to this first limit, while the endpoint of the blue arrow corresponds to the second. This distinction highlights a key aspect of grokking: the dynamics evolve on two different timescales. Initially, as described by PropositionÂ 1, the regularised flow tracks the unregularised one. But at much larger time horizons, the regularised dynamics begin to diverge.

4.2 Slow dynamics

The second part of the dynamics is harder to capture, since it happens at a time approaching infinity, when Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» approaches zero. It is done using theory of singularly perturbed systems. In the following, we associate to the unregularised flow function a mapping Ï•:â„dÃ—â„+â†’â„d:italic-Ï•â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptâ„superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\phi:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}_{+}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_Ï• : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying

Ï•â¢(w,t)=Ï•â¢(w,0)âˆ’âˆ«0tâˆ‡Fâ¢(Ï•â¢(w,s))â¢ds,âˆ€(w,t)âˆˆâ„dÃ—â„+.formulae-sequenceitalic-Ï•ğ‘¤ğ‘¡italic-Ï•ğ‘¤0superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹italic-Ï•ğ‘¤ğ‘ differential-dğ‘ for-allğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptâ„\phi(w,t)=\phi(w,0)-\int_{0}^{t}\nabla F(\phi(w,s))\ \mathrm{d}s,\qquad\forall% (w,t)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}_{+}.italic_Ï• ( italic_w , italic_t ) = italic_Ï• ( italic_w , 0 ) - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_F ( italic_Ï• ( italic_w , italic_s ) ) roman_d italic_s , âˆ€ ( italic_w , italic_t ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Note that Ï•â¢(w,t)italic-Ï•ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\phi(w,t)italic_Ï• ( italic_w , italic_t ) simply corresponds to the solution of the gradient flow of EquationÂ 2 at time tğ‘¡titalic_t when initialised in wğ‘¤witalic_w. When possible to defineâ€”i.e., when the gradient flow admits a limit point in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€”we define the mapping Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ as

Î¦â¢(w)=limtâ†’âˆÏ•â¢(w,t).Î¦ğ‘¤subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡italic-Ï•ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\Phi(w)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\phi(w,t).roman_Î¦ ( italic_w ) = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• ( italic_w , italic_t ) . (4)

Thanks to AssumptionÂ 1, the unregularised flow initialised in w0subscriptğ‘¤0w_{0}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT admits the limit point Î¦â¢(w0)Î¦subscriptğ‘¤0\Phi(w_{0})roman_Î¦ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which is necessarily a stationary point of the loss, i.e., âˆ‡Fâ¢(Î¦â¢(w0))=0âˆ‡ğ¹Î¦subscriptğ‘¤00\nabla F(\Phi(w_{0}))=0âˆ‡ italic_F ( roman_Î¦ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = 0. AssumptionÂ 2 then ensure that the mapping Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ is defined and ğ’2superscriptğ’2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on some neighbourhood of â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, thanks to a result of Falconer (1983).

Lemma 1.

If AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2 hold, there exists an open neighbourhood Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U of â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M such that Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ is defined and ğ’2superscriptğ’2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U.

Now the mapping Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ is well defined on a neighbourhood of â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, it can be used to describe the limit of the slow dynamics. For Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0, we let w~Î»:tâ†¦wÎ»â¢(t/Î»):superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†maps-toğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡ğœ†\tilde{w}^{\lambda}:t\mapsto w^{\lambda}(t/\lambda)over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_t â†¦ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t / italic_Î» ). We indeed have to adequately â€œspeed-upâ€ time to capture its behaviour. Notably, w~Î»superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies the following differential equation:

w~Ë™Î»â¢(t)=âˆ’w~Î»â¢(t)âˆ’1Î»â¢âˆ‡Fâ¢(w~Î»â¢(t))Â andÂ w~Î»â¢(0)=w0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptË™~ğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡1ğœ†âˆ‡ğ¹superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡Â andÂ superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†0subscriptğ‘¤0\begin{gathered}\dot{\tilde{w}}^{\lambda}(t)=-\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t)-\frac{1}{% \lambda}\nabla F(\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t))\quad\text{ and }\quad\tilde{w}^{% \lambda}(0)=w_{0}.\end{gathered}start_ROW start_CELL overË™ start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG âˆ‡ italic_F ( over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (5)

The slow dynamics will be shown to approximate the Riemannian flow of the squared Euclidean norm on the stationary manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M for t>0ğ‘¡0t>0italic_t > 0. This limit flow is defined by w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the solution of the following differential equation on â„+subscriptâ„\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for the function â„“2:wâ†¦â€–wâ€–22/2:subscriptâ„“2maps-toğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¤222\ell_{2}:w\mapsto\|w\|_{2}^{2}/2roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_w â†¦ âˆ¥ italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 2,

w~Ë™âˆ˜â¢(t)=âˆ’gradâ„³â¢â„“2â¢(w~âˆ˜â¢(t))Â andÂ w~âˆ˜â¢(0)=Î¦â¢(w0).formulae-sequencesuperscriptË™~ğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptgradâ„³subscriptâ„“2superscript~ğ‘¤ğ‘¡Â andÂ superscript~ğ‘¤0Î¦subscriptğ‘¤0\dot{\tilde{w}}^{\circ}(t)=-\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ \ell_{2}(\tilde{w}^{% \circ}(t))\quad\text{ and }\quad\tilde{w}^{\circ}(0)=\Phi(w_{0}).overË™ start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = roman_Î¦ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (6)

Recall that the Riemannian gradient is gradâ„³â¢â„“2â¢(w)=PKerâ¢(âˆ‡2Fâ¢(w))â¢(w)subscriptgradâ„³subscriptâ„“2ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘ƒKersuperscriptâˆ‡2ğ¹ğ‘¤ğ‘¤\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ \ell_{2}(w)=P_{\mathrm{Ker}(\nabla^{2}F(w))}(w)roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Ker ( âˆ‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) for any wâˆˆâ„³ğ‘¤â„³w\in\mathcal{M}italic_w âˆˆ caligraphic_M. Denoting Dâ¢Î¦wğ·subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¤D\Phi_{w}italic_D roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the differential of Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ at wğ‘¤witalic_w, Li etÂ al. In consequence, w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also satisfies the following differential equation:

Using this alternative description of w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can now prove our main result, given by PropositionÂ 2.

Proposition 2.

If AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2 hold, then for all T,Îµ>0ğ‘‡ğœ€0T,\varepsilon>0italic_T , italic_Îµ > 0, we have w~Î»â¢âŸ¶Î»â†’0â¢w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†â†’ğœ†0âŸ¶superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\lambda}\underset{\lambda\to 0}{\longrightarrow}\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG âŸ¶ end_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (ğ’0([Îµ,T],â„d),âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)(\mathcal{C}^{0}([\varepsilon,T],\mathbb{R}^{d}),\|\cdot\|_{\infty})( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ italic_Îµ , italic_T ] , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the unique solution on â„+subscriptâ„\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the differential equation (6).

PropositionÂ 2 states that the slow dynamics w~Î»superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges uniformly to w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0 on any compact interval of the form [Îµ,T]ğœ€ğ‘‡[\varepsilon,T][ italic_Îµ , italic_T ]. Note that excluding 00 from this interval (i.e., Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0) is necessary. Indeed, uniform convergence cannot happen on an interval of the form (0,T]0ğ‘‡(0,T]( 0 , italic_T ], since w~Î»â¢(0)=w0superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†0subscriptğ‘¤0\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(0)=w_{0}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0 and w~âˆ˜â¢(0)=Î¦â¢(w0)superscript~ğ‘¤0Î¦subscriptğ‘¤0\tilde{w}^{\circ}(0)=\Phi(w_{0})over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = roman_Î¦ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In particular, PropositionÂ 2 leads to pointwise convergence of w~Î»superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: we have

{limÎ»â†’0w~Î»â¢(0)=w0,limÎ»â†’0w~Î»â¢(t)=w~âˆ˜â¢(t)ifÂ â¢t>0.casessubscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†0subscriptğ‘¤0otherwiseformulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ifÂ ğ‘¡0otherwise\begin{cases}\lim\limits_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(0)=w_{0},\\ \lim\limits_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t)=\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)\quad% \text{if }t>0.\end{cases}{ start_ROW start_CELL roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) if italic_t > 0 . end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW

This limit function limÎ»â†’0w~Î»subscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{w}^{\lambda}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is non-continuous at 00. Indeed the whole fast dynamics, which follows the unregularised flow, happens at that 00 point in the limit Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0. On the other hand, PropositionÂ 2 describes the second phase of the dynamics, starting from the convergence point of the unregularized flow Î¦â¢(w0)Î¦subscriptğ‘¤0\Phi(w_{0})roman_Î¦ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â€“ at the rescaled time 0+superscript00^{+}0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€“ and following the Riemannian flow on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M.

Note that, once the junction between the slow and fast dynamics is carefully handled via LemmaÂ 2 in SectionÂ A.2, PropositionÂ 2 can be derived from Fatkullin etÂ al. (2010, Theorem 2.2), which heavily relies on the technical result of Katzenberger (1990). However, for the sake of completeness and readability, we provide a concise and self-contained proof of PropositionÂ 2, avoiding the use of heavyweight methods from Katzenberger (1990) and relying on weaker assumptions.

Sketch of proof.

We here provide a sketch of proof with the key arguments leading to PropositionÂ 2. Its complete and detailed proof can be found in SectionÂ A.3. We first define the shifted slow dynamics v~Î»superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0 as v~Î»â¢(t)=w~Î»â¢(t+tâ¢(Î»))superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğœ†\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)=\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t+t(\lambda))over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + italic_t ( italic_Î» ) ), where tâ¢(Î»)ğ‘¡ğœ†t(\lambda)italic_t ( italic_Î» ) is the â€œjunction pointâ€ between the two dynamics given by LemmaÂ 2 in SectionÂ A.2, and satisfies limÎ»â†’0tâ¢(Î»)=0subscriptâ†’ğœ†0ğ‘¡ğœ†0\lim_{\lambda\rightarrow 0}t(\lambda)=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ( italic_Î» ) = 0. Using LemmaÂ 2, v~Î»superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then follows the same differential equation as w~Î»superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with an initial condition now satisfying limÎ»â†’0v~Î»â¢(0)=Î¦â¢(w0)âˆˆâ„³subscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†0Î¦subscriptğ‘¤0â„³\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(0)=\Phi(w_{0})\in\mathcal{M}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = roman_Î¦ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_M. While the dynamics of v~Î»superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT might be hard to control as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0, it is easier to control the one of Î¦â¢(v~Î»)Î¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda})roman_Î¦ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Using the chain rule, we indeed have

Î¦Ë™â¢(v~Î»â¢(t))=âˆ’Dâ¢Î¦v~Î»â¢(t)â‹…(v~Î»â¢(t)+1Î»â¢âˆ‡Fâ¢(v~Î»â¢(t))).Ë™Î¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡â‹…ğ·subscriptÎ¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡1ğœ†âˆ‡ğ¹superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡\dot{\Phi}(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))=-D\Phi_{\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)}\cdot\Big{(}% \tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)+\frac{1}{\lambda}\nabla F(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))\Big{)}.overË™ start_ARG roman_Î¦ end_ARG ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) = - italic_D roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG âˆ‡ italic_F ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ) .

Then using the fact that for any wğ‘¤witalic_w in a neighbourhood of â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, Dâ¢Î¦â¢(w)â‹…âˆ‡Fâ¢(w)=0â‹…ğ·Î¦ğ‘¤âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¤0D\Phi(w)\cdot\nabla F(w)=0italic_D roman_Î¦ ( italic_w ) â‹… âˆ‡ italic_F ( italic_w ) = 0 (Li etÂ al., 2021, Lemma C.2), this directly rewrites as

Î¦Ë™â¢(v~Î»â¢(t))=âˆ’Dâ¢Î¦v~Î»â¢(t)â‹…v~Î»â¢(t).Ë™Î¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡â‹…ğ·subscriptÎ¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡\dot{\Phi}(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))=-D\Phi_{\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)}\cdot\tilde{% v}^{\lambda}(t).overË™ start_ARG roman_Î¦ end_ARG ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) = - italic_D roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) .

Now note that this resembles the differential equation satisfied by w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The two differences being that (i) the initialisation points differ, but limÎ»â†’0v~Î»â¢(0)=w~âˆ˜â¢(0)subscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†0superscript~ğ‘¤0\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(0)=\tilde{w}^{\circ}(0)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ); (ii) the time derivative is on Î¦â¢(v~Î»)Î¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda})roman_Î¦ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) rather than v~Î»superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT directly. To handle the second point, v~Î»superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î¦â¢(v~Î»)Î¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda})roman_Î¦ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) obviously converge to the same initialisation point as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0. One can then use stability of the manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, thanks to AssumptionÂ 2, to show that suptâˆˆ[0,T]â€–v~Î»â¢(t)âˆ’Î¦â¢(v~Î»â¢(t))â€–subscriptsupremumğ‘¡0ğ‘‡normsuperscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡Î¦superscript~ğ‘£ğœ†ğ‘¡\sup_{t\in[0,T]}\|\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)-\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))\|roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - roman_Î¦ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) âˆ¥ converges to 00 as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0italic_Î» â†’ 0. This then allows to conclude. âˆ

Characterizing the limit of the Riemannian flow.

By monotonicity of its norm, w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obviously bounded over time. Typical optimisation results then guarantee that the limit set of w~âˆ˜â¢(t)superscript~ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\inftyitalic_t â†’ âˆ is contained in the set of critical points of the squared Euclidean norm on the manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, given by the KKT points of the following constrained problem:

minwâˆˆâ„³â¡â€–wâ€–22.subscriptğ‘¤â„³superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¤22\min_{w\in\mathcal{M}}\|w\|_{2}^{2}.roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w âˆˆ caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (7)

The notion of KKT points indeed extend to smooth manifolds (Bergmann and Herzog, 2019), so that under AssumptionÂ 2, the KKT points of EquationÂ 7 are given by the points wâ‹†âˆˆâ„³superscriptğ‘¤â‹†â„³w^{\star}\in\mathcal{M}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_M satisfying gradâ„³â¢â„“2â¢(wâ‹†)=0subscriptgradâ„³subscriptâ„“2superscriptğ‘¤â‹†0\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ell_{2}(w^{\star})=0roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0, where we recall gradâ„³â¢â„“2subscriptgradâ„³subscriptâ„“2\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ell_{2}roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Riemannian gradient.

We are then able to show that wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges towards the set of KKT points. Note that this does not follow from PropositionÂ 2 alone, as we also need to show that trajectory of wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT remains bounded independently of Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»: we can prove this is true in our case.

Proposition 3.

If AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2 hold, then for any sequence (Î»k)kâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜ğ‘˜â„•(\lambda_{k})_{k\in\mathbb{N}}( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Î»kâ¢â†’kâ†’âˆâ¢0subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜â†’ğ‘˜â†’0\lambda_{k}\underset{k\to\infty}{\rightarrow}0italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_k â†’ âˆ end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG â†’ end_ARG 0, the limit points of (limtâ†’âˆwÎ»kâ¢(t))kâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ‘˜â„•(\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda_{k}}(t))_{k\in\mathbb{N}}( roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are included in the KKT points of EquationÂ 7.

While PropositionÂ 3 guarantees that wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT gets arbitrarily close to KKT points of EquationÂ 7 as Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» goes to 00, it does not imply that it has the same limit as w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It is however guaranteed with the additional assumption that w~âˆ˜â¢(t)superscript~ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) converges to a strict local minimum of the Euclidean norm on the manifoldÂ â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M.

Proposition 4.

Let AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2 hold and, assume additionally that wâˆ˜â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w^{\circ}(t)italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) converges towards a strict local minimum wâ‹†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†w^{\star}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the constrained problem (7). Then limÎ»â†’0limtâ†’âˆwÎ»â¢(t)=wâ‹†subscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤â‹†\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda}(t)=w^{\star}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

When the slow limit dynamics on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M converges towards a strict local minimum, PropositionÂ 4 guarantees that, for small enough Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î», wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT gets trapped in the vicinity of this local minimum as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\inftyitalic_t â†’ âˆ, allowing us to get a perfect characterisation of limÎ»â†’0limtâ†’âˆwÎ»â¢(t)subscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda}(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ). In particular, this double limit corresponds to the limit of the slow dynamics w~âˆ˜superscript~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, while the permuted limit (limtâ†’âˆlimÎ»â†’0wÎ»â¢(t)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†ğ‘¡\lim_{t\to\infty}\lim_{\lambda\to 0}w^{\lambda}(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t )) corresponds to the limit of the fast dynamics wGFsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, thanks to PropositionÂ 1.

Comparison with Lyu etÂ al. (2023).

The work most closely related to ours is that of Lyu etÂ al. (2023), which provides a theoretical characterization of the grokking phenomenon as a transition from the NTK regimeâ€”i.e., the unregularised flow initialised at large scalesâ€”to the rich regime, which typically converges to KKT points of EquationÂ 7. However, their analysis does not offer a general optimisation-based perspective on the phenomenon and, in particular, does not account for the slow drift phase along the solution manifold, which we identify and characterise. Moreover, their setting is more restrictive: it assumes specific network architectures with homogeneous parameterisation and requires large initialisation scales. In contrast, our results hold outside the NTK regime and apply across a broader class of settings. In addition, their theoretical guarantees rely on taking the initialisation scale to infinity while simultaneously letting the regularisation strength tend to zero, with both rates polynomially coupled. Their analysis establishes that, for some sufficiently large time t~â¢(Î»)~ğ‘¡ğœ†\tilde{t}(\lambda)over~ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( italic_Î» ), the regularised flow wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT approaches KKT points of EquationÂ 7, but it does not provide guarantees about the asymptotic behavior beyond this time. By contrast, PropositionÂ 3 characterises the limit points of the flow wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, offering a stronger and more complete understanding of its long-term dynamics.

5 Examples and experiments

Linear regression.

Let Fâ¢(w)=â€–Xâ¢wâˆ’yâ€–22ğ¹ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘‹ğ‘¤ğ‘¦22F(w)=\|Xw-y\|_{2}^{2}italic_F ( italic_w ) = âˆ¥ italic_X italic_w - italic_y âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Xâˆˆâ„nÃ—dğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘X\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume that minâ¡F=0ğ¹0\min F=0roman_min italic_F = 0. The problem is convex and the set of critical points is the affine subspace â„³={w:Xâ¢w=y}â„³conditional-setğ‘¤ğ‘‹ğ‘¤ğ‘¦\mathcal{M}=\{w\,:\,Xw=y\}caligraphic_M = { italic_w : italic_X italic_w = italic_y }; AssumptionÂ 2 is satisfied globally.

It is well known that unregularised gradient flow wGFsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to ğ’«â„³â¢(w0)subscriptğ’«â„³subscriptğ‘¤0\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{M}}(w_{0})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the projection of the initial point on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M. Then, since â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is convex, the Riemannian flow on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M necessarily converges to the minimal â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm solution wâ‹†=X+â¢ysuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¦w^{\star}=X^{+}yitalic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y, where X+superscriptğ‘‹X^{+}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the pseudo-inverse. Those two points are different (unless w0=0subscriptğ‘¤00w_{0}=0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0), which leads to grokking, as wâ‹†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†w^{\star}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is expected to have better generalization properties than ğ’«â„³â¢(w0)subscriptğ’«â„³subscriptğ‘¤0\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{M}}(w_{0})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Bartlett etÂ al., 2020). In this setting, the trajectories of wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be computed explicitly to illustrate the two-timescale dynamics; see AppendixÂ C.

Matrix completion.

This is a prototypical non-convex problem which is amenable to theoretical analysis. The goal is to recover a matrix Mâ‹†âˆˆâ„nÃ—msuperscriptğ‘€â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘šM^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times m}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is assumed to be low-rank, from a subset of observed entries in Î©âŠ‚[n]Ã—[m]Î©delimited-[]ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘š\Omega\subset[n]\times[m]roman_Î© âŠ‚ [ italic_n ] Ã— [ italic_m ], by solving

minUâˆˆâ„nÃ—r,Vâˆˆâ„mÃ—râ¡Fâ¢(U,V)=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆÎ©((Uâ¢VâŠ¤)iâ¢jâˆ’Miâ¢jâ‹†)2,subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘ˆsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘‰superscriptâ„ğ‘šğ‘Ÿğ¹ğ‘ˆğ‘‰subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—Î©superscriptsubscriptğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘‰topğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â‹†ğ‘–ğ‘—2\min_{U\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times r},V\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times r}}F(U,V)=\textstyle% \sum_{(i,j)\in\Omega}\left((UV^{\top})_{ij}-M^{\star}_{ij}\right)^{2},roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m Ã— italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_U , italic_V ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ( italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (8)

where rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is the target rank. If the rank of the ground truth Mâ‹†superscriptğ‘€â‹†M^{\star}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is known, one can set rğ‘Ÿritalic_r accordingly. However, the true rank is often unknown. An alternative approach is to use overparameterisation and choose rğ‘Ÿritalic_r much higher than needed. Although in this case Fğ¹Fitalic_F has many minimizers, our results indicate that the gradient flow trajectories (2) for small Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» tend to converge towards low-rank solutions.

More precisely, we analyse the extreme overparameterised setting when r=m+nğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘›r=m+nitalic_r = italic_m + italic_n. In AppendixÂ C, we show that the set â„³â‹†superscriptâ„³â‹†\mathcal{M}^{\star}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of stationary points of Fğ¹Fitalic_F which are nonsingular matrices forms a manifold. Provided that unregularised gradient flow converges to a nonsingular point, we can apply our results locally. These results state that, in the second, slow phase of the dynamics, the trajectories minimise â€–Uâ€–F2+â€–Vâ€–F2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘ˆğ¹2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘‰ğ¹2\|U\|_{F}^{2}+\|V\|_{F}^{2}âˆ¥ italic_U âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ italic_V âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on â„³â‹†superscriptâ„³â‹†\mathcal{M}^{\star}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Recall that for a given matrix Mâˆˆâ„nÃ—mğ‘€superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘šM\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times m}italic_M âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

â€–Mâ€–âˆ—=minUâ¢VâŠ¤=Mâ¡12â¢(â€–Uâ€–F2+â€–Vâ€–F2),subscriptnormğ‘€subscriptğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘‰topğ‘€12superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘ˆğ¹2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘‰ğ¹2\|M\|_{*}=\min_{UV^{\top}=M}\frac{1}{2}(\|U\|_{F}^{2}+\|V\|_{F}^{2}),âˆ¥ italic_M âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( âˆ¥ italic_U âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ italic_V âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where â€–Mâ€–âˆ—subscriptnormğ‘€\|M\|_{*}âˆ¥ italic_M âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the nuclear norm (Srebro etÂ al., 2004, Lemma 1). Since minimising the nuclear norm promotes low-rank solutions, this indicates a drift toward low-rank matrices during the slow phase of the dynamics. In AppendixÂ C, we study the more general class of matrix sensing problems and discuss an important technical subtlety: the set â„³â‹†superscriptâ„³â‹†\mathcal{M}^{\star}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT forms a manifold only after excluding degenerate points. Handling those singularities is highly non-trivial and remains an open direction for future work.

FigureÂ 2 below empirically confirms this grokking for matrix completion. We here randomly generate a rank 3333 ground truth matrix Mâ‹†âˆˆâ„20Ã—20superscriptğ‘€â‹†superscriptâ„2020M^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{20\times 20}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 20 Ã— 20 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with non-zero singular values Ïƒ1â‹†,Ïƒ2â‹†,Ïƒ3â‹†subscriptsuperscriptğœâ‹†1subscriptsuperscriptğœâ‹†2subscriptsuperscriptğœâ‹†3\sigma^{\star}_{1},\sigma^{\star}_{2},\sigma^{\star}_{3}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We randomly sample 50% of the entries to define the observed entries Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î©. We then perform gradient descent with weight decay parameter Î»=10âˆ’3ğœ†superscript103\lambda=10^{-3}italic_Î» = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and stepsize Î³=10âˆ’2ğ›¾superscript102\gamma=10^{-2}italic_Î³ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the loss Fâ¢(U,V)ğ¹ğ‘ˆğ‘‰F(U,V)italic_F ( italic_U , italic_V ) defined in EquationÂ 8 and where the weights U,Vâˆˆâ„20Ã—10ğ‘ˆğ‘‰superscriptâ„2010U,V\in\mathbb{R}^{20\times 10}italic_U , italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 20 Ã— 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are initialised with i.i.d. standard Gaussian entries. We then track the training loss, the unmasked test loss â€–Mâ‹†âˆ’Uâ¢VâŠ¤â€–Fsubscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘€â‹†ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘‰topğ¹\|M^{\star}-UV^{\top}\|_{F}âˆ¥ italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the weight norms â€–wâ€–2=â€–Uâ€–F2+â€–Vâ€–F2superscriptnormğ‘¤2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘ˆğ¹2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘‰ğ¹2\|w\|^{2}=\|U\|_{F}^{2}+\|V\|_{F}^{2}âˆ¥ italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ¥ italic_U âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ italic_V âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and singular values of the reconstruction matrix Uâ¢VâŠ¤ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘‰topUV^{\top}italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Additional experimental details can be found in SectionÂ D.1.

Explaining the observed grokking phenomenon. At time t=0ğ‘¡0t=0italic_t = 0, the weights are randomly initialised and the training loss is high. Initially, the regularised and unregularised weights follow the same trajectory, and the training loss quickly drops to zero: the regularised iterates converge to the same solution as the unregularised gradient flow. This early solution has a high norm, large singular values, and poor generalisation performance. As training continues, around time t=1/Î»ğ‘¡1ğœ†t=1/\lambdaitalic_t = 1 / italic_Î», the weight norms begin to decrease. By tâ‰ˆ104ğ‘¡superscript104t\approx 10^{4}italic_t â‰ˆ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the parameters have drifted to a new solution that still achieves zero training loss but has a much lower norm and actually coincides with the low rank ground truth matrix Mâ‹†superscriptğ‘€â‹†M^{\star}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Two-layer ReLU network.

Although our theoretical framework does not allow for non-smooth architectures such as ReLU networks, we illustrate in FigureÂ 3 that similar grokking dynamics can be observed in this case. We train a two-layer ReLU network of the form fwâ¢(x)=âˆ‘j=1mujâ¢ReLUâ¢(vjâ¢x+bj),subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¤ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—ReLUsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘—f_{w}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{m}u_{j}\,\mathrm{ReLU}(v_{j}x+b_{j}),italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ReLU ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , with weights w=(u,v,b)ğ‘¤ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘w=(u,v,b)italic_w = ( italic_u , italic_v , italic_b ) where the outer layer is uâˆˆâ„mğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘šu\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_u âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the inner weight vâˆˆâ„mğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘šv\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and bias bâˆˆâ„mğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘šb\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_b âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The teacher function fğ‘“fitalic_f is a sum of 3333 ReLUs and is represented in dotted light blue in FigureÂ 3. We generate a training dataset of n=10ğ‘›10n=10italic_n = 10 points by sampling xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniformly in [âˆ’2,2]22[-2,2][ - 2 , 2 ] and computing yi=fâ¢(xi)subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–y_{i}=f(x_{i})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). These training points are shown as black crosses in FigureÂ 3. We train the student network with m=100ğ‘š100m=100italic_m = 100 by minimising the squared loss Fâ¢(w)=12â¢nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(fwâ¢(xi)âˆ’yi)2ğ¹ğ‘¤12ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–2F(w)=\tfrac{1}{2n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(f_{w}(x_{i})-y_{i}\right)^{2}italic_F ( italic_w ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using gradient descent with weight decay Î»=10âˆ’3ğœ†superscript103\lambda=10^{-3}italic_Î» = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for T=106ğ‘‡superscript106T=10^{6}italic_T = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations and small step size. The initial weights are independently sampled from a Gaussian of varianceÂ 4444. At each iteration, we record the train loss, the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the weights, as well as the test loss over a fixed test dataset (plotted FigureÂ 3, left).

Explaining the observed grokking phenomenon. At time t1=0subscriptğ‘¡10t_{1}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the weights are randomly initialised and the training loss is high. By t2=1subscriptğ‘¡21t_{2}=1italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, the training loss has dropped to nearly zero, and the iterates closely approximate the solution that would be obtained by unregularised gradient flow, this solution does not have a low norm and generalises poorly. Subsequently, around time t=1/Î»ğ‘¡1ğœ†t=1/\lambdaitalic_t = 1 / italic_Î», the weight norms begin to decrease, and by t3â‰ˆ105subscriptğ‘¡3superscript105t_{3}\approx 10^{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, they have drifted to a zero training loss solution which has a much lower â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm and which generalises much better. Such solutions are believed to have a small number of "kinks"Â (Savarese etÂ al., 2019; Parhi and Nowak, 2021; Boursier and Flammarion, 2023), as observed in FigureÂ 3 (far right plot).

Diagonal Linear Networks.

We also studyâ€”both as an application of TheoremÂ 1 and numericallyâ€”the architecture of diagonal neural networks in AppendicesÂ C andÂ D.2, which serve as a toy problem for neural network training dynamics. In that case grokking promotes sparse estimators.

6 Conclusion

This work presents a rigorous and general optimisation-based description of the grokking phenomenon as a two-timescale process. In the fast initial phase, parameters evolve according to the unregularised flow until reaching a stationary manifold. In the slower second phase, they follow the Riemannian gradient flow of the norm constrained to this manifold. Grokking naturally emerges from a gradual simplicity bias: starting from a poorly generalising solution recovered by unregularised gradient flow, the slow phase driven by weight decay gradually simplifies the model by reducing its norm, ultimately leading to better generalisation.

While prior work has extensively analysed the first phase via the implicit bias of optimisation algorithms, the second phaseâ€”norm minimisation constrained to the interpolation manifoldâ€”has received little attention. Our framework highlights the critical role of this phase and motivates further study of optimisation dynamics on interpolation manifolds.

Large initialisations (NTK regime) are known to yield poor generalisation (Chizat etÂ al., 2019; Liu etÂ al., 2022c), while small initialisations (rich regime) can lead to slow convergence or convergence to suboptimal solutions for the training lossÂ (Boursier and Flammarion, 2024a, b). Grokking may offer a desirable compromise, achieving fast convergence to an interpolating solution while retaining strong generalisation.

Lastly, our analysis focuses on regression settings with bounded dynamics. In classification tasks, by contrast, the stationary manifold lies â€œat infinityâ€ once interpolation is achieved. Extending our approach to such settings remains an open and promising direction for future work, likely requiring techniques tailored to classification losses.

Paris interdisciplinary research center composed of Institut Polytechnique de Paris (IP Paris) and HEC Paris.
