Since uÎ»â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¢ğœ†ğ‘¡u^{\lambda}(t)italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) is continuous, it implies that uÎ»â¢(t)âˆˆUÎµâˆ˜superscriptğ‘¢ğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ˆğœ€u^{\lambda}(t)\in\overset{\circ}{U_{\varepsilon}}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) âˆˆ overâˆ˜ start_ARG italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG for any tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0, which concludes the proof of LemmaÂ 3. âˆ

B.6 Strict Minimality

Lemma 8.

Under the same assumptions than PropositionÂ 4 with wâ‹†=limtâ†’âˆw~âˆ˜â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¤â‹†subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘¤ğ‘¡w^{\star}=\lim_{t\to\infty}\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ), there exists a Î´â‹†>0superscriptğ›¿â‹†0\delta^{\star}>0italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 such that for any Î´âˆˆ(0,Î´â‹†)ğ›¿0superscriptğ›¿â‹†\delta\in(0,\delta^{\star})italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), there exists Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0 and Î»â‹†>0superscriptğœ†â‹†0\lambda^{\star}>0italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 such that for any Î»âˆˆ(0,Î»â‹†)ğœ†0superscriptğœ†â‹†\lambda\in(0,\lambda^{\star})italic_Î» âˆˆ ( 0 , italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

infâˆ‚Bâ¢(wâ‹†,Î´)FÎ»â¢(w)>Fâ‹†+Î»â¢â€–wâ‹†â€–22+Î»â¢Îµ.subscriptinfimumğµsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğ›¿subscriptğ¹ğœ†ğ‘¤superscriptğ¹â‹†ğœ†superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†22ğœ†ğœ€\inf_{\partial B(w^{\star},\delta)}F_{\lambda}(w)>F^{\star}+\lambda\frac{\|w^{% \star}\|^{2}}{2}+\lambda\varepsilon.roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‚ italic_B ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î´ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) > italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î» divide start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_Î» italic_Îµ . (22)
Proof.

Let Î´â‹†>0superscriptğ›¿â‹†0\delta^{\star}>0italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 be such that for any wâˆˆâ„³âˆ©Bâ¢(wâ‹†,2â¢Î´â‹†)ğ‘¤â„³ğµsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2superscriptğ›¿â‹†w\in\mathcal{M}\cap B(w^{\star},2\delta^{\star})italic_w âˆˆ caligraphic_M âˆ© italic_B ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 2 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), wâ‰ wâ‹†âŸ¹â€–wâ€–2>â€–wâ‹†â€–2ğ‘¤superscriptğ‘¤â‹†superscriptnormğ‘¤2superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2w\neq w^{\star}\implies\|w\|^{2}>\|w^{\star}\|^{2}italic_w â‰  italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¹ âˆ¥ italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and such that EquationÂ 14 holds. Now let Î´âˆˆ(0,Î´â‹†)ğ›¿0superscriptğ›¿â‹†\delta\in(0,\delta^{\star})italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We now fix Î»â‹†>0superscriptğœ†â‹†0\lambda^{\star}>0italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 arbitrarily small, choose Î»âˆˆ(0,Î»â‹†)ğœ†0superscriptğœ†â‹†\lambda\in(0,\lambda^{\star})italic_Î» âˆˆ ( 0 , italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and define

Îµ=14â¢infuâˆˆâ„³Î´2â‰¤â€–uâˆ’wâ‹†â€–â‰¤2â¢Î´â€–uâ€–22âˆ’â€–wâ‹†â€–22.ğœ€14subscriptinfimumğ‘¢â„³ğ›¿2normğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¢22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†22\varepsilon=\frac{1}{4}\inf_{\begin{subarray}{c}u\in\mathcal{M}\\ \frac{\delta}{2}\leq\|u-w^{\star}\|\leq 2\delta\end{subarray}}\|u\|_{2}^{2}-\|% w^{\star}\|_{2}^{2}.italic_Îµ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_u âˆˆ caligraphic_M end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_u - italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 2 italic_Î´ end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

By strict minimality, compactness and continuity, Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0.

Let now wâˆˆâˆ‚Bâ¢(wâ‹†,Î´)ğ‘¤ğµsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğ›¿w\in\partial B(w^{\star},\delta)italic_w âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_B ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î´ ). We can decompose wğ‘¤witalic_w as w=u+vğ‘¤ğ‘¢ğ‘£w=u+vitalic_w = italic_u + italic_v, where uâˆˆargâ¢minwâ€²âˆˆâ„³â¢â€–wâˆ’wâ€²â€–ğ‘¢argsubscriptminsuperscriptğ‘¤â€²â„³normğ‘¤superscriptğ‘¤â€²u\in\mathrm{arg\ min\ }_{w^{\prime}\in\mathcal{M}}\|w-w^{\prime}\|italic_u âˆˆ roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_w - italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥. Necessarily, â€–vâ€–=dâ¢(w,â„³)â‰¤Î´normğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘¤â„³ğ›¿\|v\|=d(w,\mathcal{M})\leq\deltaâˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ = italic_d ( italic_w , caligraphic_M ) â‰¤ italic_Î´ and â€–wâˆ’wâ‹†â€–=Î´normğ‘¤superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğ›¿\|w-w^{\star}\|=\deltaâˆ¥ italic_w - italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ = italic_Î´. In particular, we also have 2â¢Î´â‰¥â€–uâˆ’wâ‹†â€–â‰¥Î´âˆ’â€–vâ€–2ğ›¿normğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğ›¿normğ‘£2\delta\geq\|u-w^{\star}\|\geq\delta-\|v\|2 italic_Î´ â‰¥ âˆ¥ italic_u - italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¥ italic_Î´ - âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥. From there, using the quadratic growth property (EquationÂ 14):

FÎ»â¢(w)subscriptğ¹ğœ†ğ‘¤\displaystyle F_{\lambda}(w)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) â‰¥Fâ¢(w)+Î»2â¢(â€–uâ€–âˆ’â€–vâ€–)2absentğ¹ğ‘¤ğœ†2superscriptnormğ‘¢normğ‘£2\displaystyle\geq F(w)+\frac{\lambda}{2}(\|u\|-\|v\|)^{2}â‰¥ italic_F ( italic_w ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ - âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
â‰¥Fâ‹†+Î·4â¢dâ¢(w,â„³)2+Î»2â¢(â€–uâ€–2âˆ’2â¢â€–uâ€–â¢â€–vâ€–)absentsuperscriptğ¹â‹†ğœ‚4ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¤â„³2ğœ†2superscriptnormğ‘¢22normğ‘¢normğ‘£\displaystyle\geq F^{\star}+\frac{\eta}{4}d(w,\mathcal{M})^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{% 2}(\|u\|^{2}-2\|u\|\|v\|)â‰¥ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_d ( italic_w , caligraphic_M ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ )
â‰¥FÎ»â¢(wâ‹†)+Î·4â¢dâ¢(w,â„³)2âˆ’Î»â¢(â€–wâ‹†â€–+2â¢Î´)â¢â€–vâ€–+Î»2â¢(â€–uâ€–2âˆ’â€–wâ‹†â€–2).absentsubscriptğ¹ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğœ‚4ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¤â„³2ğœ†normsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿normğ‘£ğœ†2superscriptnormğ‘¢2superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2\displaystyle\geq F_{\lambda}(w^{\star})+\frac{\eta}{4}d(w,\mathcal{M})^{2}-% \lambda(\|w^{\star}\|+2\delta)\|v\|+\frac{\lambda}{2}(\|u\|^{2}-\|w^{\star}\|^% {2}).â‰¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_d ( italic_w , caligraphic_M ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î´ ) âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ + divide start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Let câ¢(Îµ,Î´)=minâ¡(Î´2;Îµâ€–wâ‹†â€–+2â¢Î´)>0ğ‘ğœ€ğ›¿ğ›¿2ğœ€normsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿0c(\varepsilon,\delta)=\min(\frac{\delta}{2};\frac{\varepsilon}{\|w^{\star}\|+2% \delta})>0italic_c ( italic_Îµ , italic_Î´ ) = roman_min ( divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ; divide start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î´ end_ARG ) > 0. There are two cases.

1) Either â€–vâ€–â‰¤câ¢(Îµ,Î´)normğ‘£ğ‘ğœ€ğ›¿\|v\|\leq c(\varepsilon,\delta)âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_c ( italic_Îµ , italic_Î´ ), in which case 2â¢Î´â‰¥â€–uâˆ’wâ‹†â€–â‰¥Î´22ğ›¿normğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğ›¿22\delta\geq\|u-w^{\star}\|\geq\frac{\delta}{2}2 italic_Î´ â‰¥ âˆ¥ italic_u - italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, so that by definition of Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ

FÎ»â¢(w)subscriptğ¹ğœ†ğ‘¤\displaystyle F_{\lambda}(w)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) â‰¥FÎ»â¢(wâ‹†)âˆ’Î»â¢(â€–wâ‹†â€–+2â¢Î´)â¢â€–vâ€–+Î»2â¢(â€–uâ€–2âˆ’â€–wâ‹†â€–2)absentsubscriptğ¹ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğœ†normsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿normğ‘£ğœ†2superscriptnormğ‘¢2superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2\displaystyle\geq F_{\lambda}(w^{\star})-\lambda(\|w^{\star}\|+2\delta)\|v\|+% \frac{\lambda}{2}(\|u\|^{2}-\|w^{\star}\|^{2})â‰¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î´ ) âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ + divide start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
â‰¥FÎ»â¢(wâ‹†)âˆ’Î»â¢(â€–wâ‹†â€–+2â¢Î´)â¢câ¢(Îµ,Î´)+Î»2â‹…4â¢Îµabsentsubscriptğ¹ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğœ†normsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿ğ‘ğœ€ğ›¿â‹…ğœ†24ğœ€\displaystyle\geq F_{\lambda}(w^{\star})-\lambda(\|w^{\star}\|+2\delta)c(% \varepsilon,\delta)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\cdot 4\varepsilonâ‰¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î´ ) italic_c ( italic_Îµ , italic_Î´ ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‹… 4 italic_Îµ
â‰¥FÎ»â¢(wâ‹†)+Î»â¢Îµ.absentsubscriptğ¹ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğœ†ğœ€\displaystyle\geq F_{\lambda}(w^{\star})+\lambda\varepsilon.â‰¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Î» italic_Îµ .

2) Or â€–vâ€–â‰¥câ¢(Îµ,Î´)normğ‘£ğ‘ğœ€ğ›¿\|v\|\geq c(\varepsilon,\delta)âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ â‰¥ italic_c ( italic_Îµ , italic_Î´ ), in which case we simply have, also using that â€–vâ€–â‰¤Î´normğ‘£ğ›¿\|v\|\leq\deltaâˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_Î´:

FÎ»â¢(w)subscriptğ¹ğœ†ğ‘¤\displaystyle F_{\lambda}(w)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) â‰¥FÎ»â¢(wâ‹†)+Î·4â¢â€–vâ€–2âˆ’Î»â¢(â€–wâ‹†â€–+2â¢Î´)â¢â€–vâ€–absentsubscriptğ¹ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğœ‚4superscriptnormğ‘£2ğœ†normsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿normğ‘£\displaystyle\geq F_{\lambda}(w^{\star})+\frac{\eta}{4}\|v\|^{2}-\lambda(\|w^{% \star}\|+2\delta)\|v\|â‰¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î´ ) âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥
â‰¥FÎ»â¢(wâ‹†)+Î·4â¢câ¢(Îµ,Î´)2âˆ’Î»â¢(â€–wâ‹†â€–+2â¢Î´)â¢Î´.absentsubscriptğ¹ğœ†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†ğœ‚4ğ‘superscriptğœ€ğ›¿2ğœ†normsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿ğ›¿\displaystyle\geq F_{\lambda}(w^{\star})+\frac{\eta}{4}c(\varepsilon,\delta)^{% 2}-\lambda(\|w^{\star}\|+2\delta)\delta.â‰¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_c ( italic_Îµ , italic_Î´ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î´ ) italic_Î´ .

In particular, choosing Î»â‹†superscriptğœ†â‹†\lambda^{\star}italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT small enough â€“ depending on Î·,Îµğœ‚ğœ€\eta,\varepsilonitalic_Î· , italic_Îµ and Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ â€“ we have for any Î»â‰¤Î»â‹†ğœ†superscriptğœ†â‹†\lambda\leq\lambda^{\star}italic_Î» â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that

Î·4â¢câ¢(Îµ,Î´)2âˆ’Î»â¢(â€–wâ‹†â€–+2â¢Î´)â¢Î´â‰¥Î»â¢Îµ.ğœ‚4ğ‘superscriptğœ€ğ›¿2ğœ†normsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†2ğ›¿ğ›¿ğœ†ğœ€\displaystyle\frac{\eta}{4}c(\varepsilon,\delta)^{2}-\lambda(\|w^{\star}\|+2% \delta)\delta\geq\lambda\varepsilon.divide start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_c ( italic_Îµ , italic_Î´ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î´ ) italic_Î´ â‰¥ italic_Î» italic_Îµ .

So that in both cases, FÎ»â¢(w)>Fâ‹†+Î»â¢â€–wâ‹†â€–22+Î»â¢Îµsubscriptğ¹ğœ†ğ‘¤superscriptğ¹â‹†ğœ†superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†22ğœ†ğœ€F_{\lambda}(w)>F^{\star}+\lambda\frac{\|w^{\star}\|^{2}}{2}+\lambda\varepsilonitalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) > italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î» divide start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_Î» italic_Îµ. âˆ

Appendix C Applications

In this section, we provide additional details to the examples discussed in SectionÂ 5, and specify how our theoretical results can be applied in various settings.

Linear regression.

We consider Fâ¢(w)=â€–Xâ¢wâˆ’yâ€–22ğ¹ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘‹ğ‘¤ğ‘¦22F(w)=\|Xw-y\|_{2}^{2}italic_F ( italic_w ) = âˆ¥ italic_X italic_w - italic_y âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Xâˆˆâ„nÃ—dğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘X\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and nâ‰¤dğ‘›ğ‘‘n\leq ditalic_n â‰¤ italic_d; assume for simplicity that Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is full rank. In this setting, the dynamics can be computed explicitely to illustrate our result.

Denote the solution of minimal â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm with wâ‹†=X+â¢ysuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¦w^{\star}=X^{+}yitalic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y, where X+superscriptğ‘‹X^{+}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X. The problem is convex and the critical set of Fğ¹Fitalic_F is the affine subspace â„³=wâ‹†+Kerâ¢(X)â„³superscriptğ‘¤â‹†Kerğ‘‹\mathcal{M}=w^{\star}+\mathrm{Ker}(X)caligraphic_M = italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Ker ( italic_X ), which is a manifold: AssumptionÂ 2 is satisfied.

Consider the singular value decomposition X=Uâ¢Î£â¢VâŠ¤ğ‘‹ğ‘ˆÎ£superscriptğ‘‰topX=U\Sigma V^{\top}italic_X = italic_U roman_Î£ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where Uâˆˆâ„nÃ—d,Vâˆˆâ„dÃ—dformulae-sequenceğ‘ˆsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘‰superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘U\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d},V\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}italic_U âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are orthogonal and Î£=diagâ¢(Ïƒ1,â€¦,Ïƒd)Î£diagsubscriptğœ1â€¦subscriptğœğ‘‘\Sigma=\mathrm{diag}(\sigma_{1},\dots,\sigma_{d})roman_Î£ = roman_diag ( italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with Ïƒn+1=â‹¯=Ïƒd=0subscriptğœğ‘›1â‹¯subscriptğœğ‘‘0\sigma_{n+1}=\dots=\sigma_{d}=0italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = â‹¯ = italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. We make the change of coordinates z=VâŠ¤â¢wğ‘§superscriptğ‘‰topğ‘¤z=V^{\top}witalic_z = italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w, and notice that in this basis the minimum norm solution zâ‹†=VâŠ¤â¢wâ‹†superscriptğ‘§â‹†superscriptğ‘‰topsuperscriptğ‘¤â‹†z^{\star}=V^{\top}w^{\star}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is of the form zâ‹†=(z1â‹†,â€¦â¢znâ‹†,0,â€¦,0)superscriptğ‘§â‹†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§â‹†1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§â‹†ğ‘›0â€¦0z^{\star}=(z^{\star}_{1},\dots z^{\star}_{n},0,\dots,0)italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 , â€¦ , 0 ). Then, we can compute the trajectory of the gradient flow on FÎ»subscriptğ¹ğœ†F_{\lambda}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT initialized at zâ¢(0)=VâŠ¤â¢w0ğ‘§0superscriptğ‘‰topsubscriptğ‘¤0z(0)=V^{\top}w_{0}italic_z ( 0 ) = italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

  • â€¢

    for 1â‰¤iâ‰¤n1ğ‘–ğ‘›1\leq i\leq n1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ italic_n,

    ziÎ»â¢(t)=ziÎ»,âˆ+eâˆ’(Ïƒi2+Î»)â¢tâ¢(ziâ¢(0)âˆ’ziÎ»,âˆ)withziÎ»,âˆ=Ïƒi2Ïƒi2+Î»â¢ziâ‹†,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğœ†ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğœ†superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2ğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğœ†withsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2ğœ†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§â‹†ğ‘–z_{i}^{\lambda}(t)=z_{i}^{\lambda,\infty}+e^{-(\sigma_{i}^{2}+\lambda)t}\left(% z_{i}(0)-z_{i}^{\lambda,\infty}\right)\quad\text{with}\quad z_{i}^{\lambda,% \infty}=\frac{\sigma_{i}^{2}}{\sigma_{i}^{2}+\lambda}z^{\star}_{i},italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» , âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î» ) italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» , âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» , âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î» end_ARG italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (23)
  • â€¢

    for (n+1)â‰¤iâ‰¤dğ‘›1ğ‘–ğ‘‘(n+1)\leq i\leq d( italic_n + 1 ) â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ italic_d,

    ziÎ»â¢(t)=eâˆ’Î»â¢tâ¢ziâ¢(0).superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğœ†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–0z_{i}^{\lambda}(t)=e^{-\lambda t}z_{i}(0).italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) . (24)

Eq. (23) describes the dynamics along the directions orthogonal to â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, and Eq. (24) along those parallel toÂ â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M. When Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\rightarrow 0italic_Î» â†’ 0, the first is much faster than the second. In the first phase, the iterates converge to (z1Î»,âˆ,â€¦â¢znÎ»,âˆ,zn+1â¢(0),â€¦,zdâ¢(0))â‰ˆÎ»â†’0(z1â‹†,â€¦â¢znâ‹†,zn+1â¢(0),â€¦,zdâ¢(0))superscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscriptsubscriptğ‘§1ğœ†â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğœ†subscriptğ‘§ğ‘›10â€¦subscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘0superscriptsubscriptğ‘§1â‹†â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›â‹†subscriptğ‘§ğ‘›10â€¦subscriptğ‘§ğ‘‘0(z_{1}^{\lambda,\infty},\dots z_{n}^{\lambda,\infty},z_{n+1}(0),\dots,z_{d}(0)% )\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\lambda\rightarrow 0}}{{\approx}}(z_{1}^{\star},\dots z% _{n}^{\star},z_{n+1}(0),\dots,z_{d}(0))( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» , âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» , âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) , â€¦ , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰ˆ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» â†’ 0 end_ARG end_RELOP ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) , â€¦ , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) ); this is the limit of unregularised gradient flow zGFsuperscriptğ‘§GFz^{\rm GF}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (which is also here the projection of the initial point ontoÂ â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M). In the second phase, the iterates converge slowly towards the mimimum norm solution (z1â‹†,â€¦â¢znâ‹†,0,â€¦,0)superscriptsubscriptğ‘§1â‹†â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›â‹†0â€¦0(z_{1}^{\star},\dots z_{n}^{\star},0,\dots,0)( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 , â€¦ , 0 ).

Diagonal linear networks (DLNs).

DLNs serve as a toy example to understand the influence of the architecture on the training dynamics of neural networks [Pesme, 2024]. The corresponding optimization problem writes

min(w1,w2)âˆˆâ„2â¢dâ¡â€–Xâ¢(w1âŠ™w2)âˆ’yâ€–22,subscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤2superscriptâ„2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘‹direct-productsubscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤2ğ‘¦22\min_{(w_{1},w_{2})\in\mathbb{R}^{2d}}\|X(w_{1}\odot w_{2})-y\|_{2}^{2},roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_X ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ™ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_y âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where âŠ™direct-product\odotâŠ™ denotes the componentwise product, and Xâˆˆâ„nÃ—dğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘X\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the feature matrix with nâ‰¤dğ‘›ğ‘‘n\leq ditalic_n â‰¤ italic_d, which we assume to be full rank. It is usually convenient to perform a rotation of the coordinates and rewrite the problem as

min(u,v)âˆˆâ„2â¢dâ¡Fâ¢(u,v)=â€–Xâ¢(u2âˆ’v2)âˆ’yâ€–22,subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£superscriptâ„2ğ‘‘ğ¹ğ‘¢ğ‘£superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘‹superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2ğ‘¦22\min_{(u,v)\in\mathbb{R}^{2d}}F(u,v)=\|X(u^{2}-v^{2})-y\|_{2}^{2},roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u , italic_v ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_u , italic_v ) = âˆ¥ italic_X ( italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where u2,v2superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2u^{2},v^{2}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the componentwise square. The critical set of Fğ¹Fitalic_F is composed of the couples (u,v)ğ‘¢ğ‘£(u,v)( italic_u , italic_v ) satisfying

uâŠ™vâŠ™[XâŠ¤â¢(Xâ¢(u2âˆ’v2)âˆ’y)]=0,direct-productğ‘¢ğ‘£delimited-[]superscriptğ‘‹topğ‘‹superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2ğ‘¦0u\odot v\odot\left[X^{\top}(X(u^{2}-v^{2})-y)\right]=0,\\ italic_u âŠ™ italic_v âŠ™ [ italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X ( italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y ) ] = 0 , (25)

This set has singularities for points who have null coordinates; if we exclude those problematic points, we can show that it is a manifold.

Proposition 5.

The set â„³âˆ—=âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ©(â„âˆ—)2â¢dsuperscriptâ„³âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10superscriptsuperscriptâ„2ğ‘‘\mathcal{M}^{*}=\nabla F^{-1}(0)\cap(\mathbb{R}^{*})^{2d}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) âˆ© ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a smooth manifold of dimension 2â¢dâˆ’n2ğ‘‘ğ‘›2d-n2 italic_d - italic_n.

Proof.

Let (uÂ¯,vÂ¯)âˆˆâ„³âˆ—Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘£superscriptâ„³(\bar{u},\bar{v})\in\mathcal{M}^{*}( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG ) âˆˆ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Denote Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W a neighborhood of (uÂ¯,vÂ¯)Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘£(\bar{u},\bar{v})( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG ) such that UâŠ‚(â„âˆ—)2â¢dğ‘ˆsuperscriptsuperscriptâ„2ğ‘‘U\subset(\mathbb{R}^{*})^{2d}italic_U âŠ‚ ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It is clear that, since all coordinates of (uÂ¯,vÂ¯)Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘£(\bar{u},\bar{v})( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG ) are nonzero, the map (Î”â¢u,Î”â¢v)â†¦uÂ¯âŠ™Î”â¢uâˆ’vÂ¯âŠ™Î”â¢vmaps-toÎ”ğ‘¢Î”ğ‘£direct-productÂ¯ğ‘¢Î”ğ‘¢direct-productÂ¯ğ‘£Î”ğ‘£(\Delta u,\Delta v)\mapsto\bar{u}\odot\Delta u-\bar{v}\odot\Delta v( roman_Î” italic_u , roman_Î” italic_v ) â†¦ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG âŠ™ roman_Î” italic_u - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG âŠ™ roman_Î” italic_v is a surjection on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and therefore rankâ¢(Dâ¢Hâ¢(uÂ¯,vÂ¯))=rankâ¢(XâŠ¤â¢X)=nrankğ·ğ»Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘£ranksuperscriptğ‘‹topğ‘‹ğ‘›\text{rank}(DH(\bar{u},\bar{v}))=\text{rank}(X^{\top}X)=nrank ( italic_D italic_H ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG ) ) = rank ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X ) = italic_n. This proves that â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a manifold of dimension 2â¢dâˆ’n2ğ‘‘ğ‘›2d-n2 italic_d - italic_n [Boumal, 2023, Â§3.2]. âˆ

Because of the singular points in â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, the function Fğ¹Fitalic_F does not satisfy AssumptionÂ 2 globally. However, our results can still be applied locally: see the paragraph below for details.

Noting that, for a vector wâˆˆâ„dğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_w âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

â€–wâ€–1=minu,vâˆˆâ„dâ¡â€–uâ€–22+â€–vâ€–22â¢subject toÂ â¢u2âˆ’v2=w,subscriptnormğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¢22superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘£22subject toÂ superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2ğ‘¤\|w\|_{1}=\min_{u,v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|u\|_{2}^{2}+\|v\|_{2}^{2}\;\;\text{% subject to }\;u^{2}-v^{2}=w,âˆ¥ italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT subject to italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_w ,

we conclude that in the second, slow phase of the dynamics, the Riemannian gradient flow which minimizes â€–uâ€–2+â€–vâ€–2superscriptnormğ‘¢2superscriptnormğ‘£2\|u\|^{2}+\|v\|^{2}âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tends to drift towards solutions of low â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm.

Low-rank matrix sensing/completion.

Let ğ’œ:ğ•Šnâ†’â„m:ğ’œâ†’superscriptğ•Šğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘š\mathcal{A}:\mathbb{S}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{m}caligraphic_A : blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a linear map on symmetric matrices with mâ‰¤n2ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘›2m\leq n^{2}italic_m â‰¤ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and yâˆˆâ„mğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘šy\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_y âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For a given target rank râ‰¤nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r\leq nitalic_r â‰¤ italic_n, the matrix sensing problem is

minWâˆˆâ„nÃ—râ¡Fâ¢(W)=â€–ğ’œâ¢(Wâ¢WâŠ¤)âˆ’yâ€–22subscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ¹ğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptnormğ’œğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Štopğ‘¦22\min_{W\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times r}}F(W)=\|\mathcal{A}(WW^{\top})-y\|_{2}^{2}roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_W ) = âˆ¥ caligraphic_A ( italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (26)

A typical example is symmetric matrix completion, where the goal is to recover an unknown matrix Mâˆ—âˆˆâ„nÃ—nsuperscriptğ‘€superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›M^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from a subset of observed entries with coefficients in Î©âˆˆ{1â¢â€¦â¢n}2Î©superscript1â€¦ğ‘›2\Omega\in\{1\dots n\}^{2}roman_Î© âˆˆ { 1 â€¦ italic_n } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: the objective function writes Fâ¢(W)=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆÎ©((Wâ¢WâŠ¤)iâ¢jâˆ’Miâ¢jâˆ—)2ğ¹ğ‘Šsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—Î©superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Štopğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—2F(W)=\sum_{(i,j)\in\Omega}\left((WW^{\top})_{ij}-M_{ij}^{*}\right)^{2}italic_F ( italic_W ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ( italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that the asymmetric case presented in SectionÂ 5, EquationÂ 8, can also be written as a symmetric matrix completion problem, by setting

W=[UV]âˆˆâ„(n+m)Ã—r,ğ‘Šmatrixğ‘ˆğ‘‰superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ŸW=\begin{bmatrix}U\\ V\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{(n+m)\times r},italic_W = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_U end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_V end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n + italic_m ) Ã— italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and choosing a new mask Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© that selects only the off-diagonal blocks of Wâ¢WâŠ¤ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠtopWW^{\top}italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Usually, one looks for a low-rank solution to Problem (26), by setting rğ‘Ÿritalic_r to a small value. Here, we choose to rather study the overparameterised setting where r=nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r=nitalic_r = italic_n. Our results imply that, even though we do not explicitly impose a low rank structure, the gradient flow trajectories WÎ»superscriptğ‘Šğœ†W^{\lambda}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are driven towards a low-rank solution in the second phase of the dynamics.

Similarly to the example of diagonal linear networks, we show that, in the overparameterised setting, the critical set of Fğ¹Fitalic_F is a manifold if we exclude singular matrices.

Proposition 6.

Let Fğ¹Fitalic_F be the matrix sensing function defined in (26), and denote â„âˆ—nÃ—nsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}_{*}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the set of invertible matrices of size nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times nitalic_n Ã— italic_n. If r=nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r=nitalic_r = italic_n, the set â„³âˆ—=âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ©â„âˆ—nÃ—nsuperscriptâ„³âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›\mathcal{M}^{*}=\nabla F^{-1}(0)\cap\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}_{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) âˆ© blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a smooth manifold.

Proof.

The gradient of Fğ¹Fitalic_F is

âˆ‡Fâ¢(W)=4â¢ğ’œâˆ—â¢(ğ’œâ¢(Wâ¢WâŠ¤)âˆ’y)â¢W,âˆ€Wâˆˆâ„nÃ—n,formulae-sequenceâˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘Š4superscriptğ’œğ’œğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Štopğ‘¦ğ‘Šfor-allğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›\nabla F(W)=4\mathcal{A}^{*}\left(\mathcal{A}(WW^{\top})-y\right)W,\quad% \forall W\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n},âˆ‡ italic_F ( italic_W ) = 4 caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ( italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y ) italic_W , âˆ€ italic_W âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where ğ’œâˆ—:â„mâ†’ğ•Šn:superscriptğ’œâ†’superscriptâ„ğ‘šsuperscriptğ•Šğ‘›\mathcal{A}^{*}:\mathbb{R}^{m}\to\mathbb{S}^{n}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the adjoint of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A.

Let WÂ¯âˆˆâ„³âˆ—Â¯ğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„³\overline{W}\in\mathcal{M}^{*}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG âˆˆ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and let ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U a neighborhood of WÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Š\overline{W}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG such that ğ’°âŠ‚â„âˆ—nÃ—nğ’°subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›\mathcal{U}\subset\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}_{*}caligraphic_U âŠ‚ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For Wâˆˆğ’°ğ‘Šğ’°W\in\mathcal{U}italic_W âˆˆ caligraphic_U, Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is invertible and we have Wâˆˆâ„³âˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„³W\in\mathcal{M}^{*}italic_W âˆˆ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if and only if ğ’œâˆ—â¢(ğ’œâ¢(Wâ¢WâŠ¤)âˆ’y)=0superscriptğ’œğ’œğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Štopğ‘¦0\mathcal{A}^{*}(\mathcal{A}(WW^{\top})-y)=0caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ( italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y ) = 0. The function Hâ¢(W)=ğ’œâˆ—â¢(ğ’œâ¢(Wâ¢WâŠ¤)âˆ’y)ğ»ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ’œğ’œğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Štopğ‘¦H(W)=\mathcal{A}^{*}(\mathcal{A}(WW^{\top})-y)italic_H ( italic_W ) = caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ( italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y ) is therefore a local defining function for â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Its differential at WÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Š\overline{W}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG satisfies for Uâˆˆâ„nÃ—nğ‘ˆsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›U\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}italic_U âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

Dâ¢Hâ¢(WÂ¯)â¢[U]=ğ’œâˆ—â¢Aâ¢(WÂ¯â¢UâŠ¤+Uâ¢WÂ¯âŠ¤).ğ·ğ»Â¯ğ‘Šdelimited-[]ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ’œğ´Â¯ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ˆtopğ‘ˆsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘ŠtopDH(\overline{W})[U]=\mathcal{A}^{*}A(\overline{W}U^{\top}+U\overline{W}^{\top}).italic_D italic_H ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG ) [ italic_U ] = caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_U overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Since WÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Š\overline{W}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG is invertible, the map Ï•:Uâ†¦WÂ¯â¢UâŠ¤+Uâ¢WÂ¯âŠ¤:italic-Ï•maps-toğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ˆtopğ‘ˆsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Štop\phi:U\mapsto\overline{W}U^{\top}+U\overline{W}^{\top}italic_Ï• : italic_U â†¦ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_U overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a surjection from â„nÃ—nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT onto ğ•Šnsuperscriptğ•Šğ‘›\mathbb{S}^{n}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: indeed, note that for any Zâˆˆğ•Šnğ‘superscriptğ•Šğ‘›Z\in\mathbb{S}^{n}italic_Z âˆˆ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have Ï•â¢(U)=Zitalic-Ï•ğ‘ˆğ‘\phi\left(U\right)=Zitalic_Ï• ( italic_U ) = italic_Z with U=12â¢Zâ¢(WÂ¯âˆ’1)âŠ¤ğ‘ˆ12ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Š1topU=\frac{1}{2}Z(\overline{W}^{-1})^{\top}italic_U = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_Z ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, the rank of Dâ¢Hâ¢(WÂ¯)ğ·ğ»Â¯ğ‘ŠDH(\overline{W})italic_D italic_H ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG ) is equal to the rank of ğ’œâˆ—â¢ğ’œsuperscriptğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}^{*}\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_A for any WÂ¯âˆˆâ„³âˆ—Â¯ğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„³\overline{W}\in\mathcal{M}^{*}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG âˆˆ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which proves that â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a smooth manifold. âˆ

Dealing with singularities.

In the last two examples, the set âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) has singular points, and so AssumptionÂ 2 does not hold globally. However, we showed that it holds on â€œmost of the spaceâ€, as there exists a negligible set ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S such that â„³âˆ—=âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ–ğ’®superscriptâ„³âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10ğ’®\mathcal{M}^{*}=\nabla F^{-1}(0)\setminus\mathcal{S}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) âˆ– caligraphic_S is a smooth manifold.

Our results can still be applied locally, assuming that the unregularised gradient flow wGFsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to a point wâˆGFâˆˆâ„³âˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤GFsuperscriptâ„³w^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}\in\mathcal{M}^{*}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Indeed, in that case there exists a neighborhood ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U of wâˆGFsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that âˆ‡Fâˆ’1â¢(0)âˆ©ğ’°âˆ‡superscriptğ¹10ğ’°\nabla F^{-1}(0)\cap\mathcal{U}âˆ‡ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) âˆ© caligraphic_U is included in â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, the Morse-Bott property holds in this neighborhood.

Consider then the Riemannian gradient flow wâˆ˜superscriptğ‘¤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm on â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT initialized at wâˆGFsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For any time horizon Tğ‘‡Titalic_T such that the trajectory of wâˆ˜superscriptğ‘¤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT stays in ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U on the interval [0,T]0ğ‘‡[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ], we can restrict our analysis to this local region, where our assumptions are satisfied. We can then invoke PropositionÂ 2 to conclude that w~Î»superscript~ğ‘¤ğœ†\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to wâˆ˜superscriptğ‘¤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT uniformly on intervals of the form [Ïµ,T]italic-Ïµğ‘‡[\epsilon,T][ italic_Ïµ , italic_T ].

However, a key limitation arises when analyzing the long-time behavior: the results characterizing the limit points ( PropositionÂ 4) do not apply if wâˆ˜superscriptğ‘¤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ˜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to a singular point outside â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This situation can occur, as singular points might correspond to points that minimize the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm on â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (e.g., sparse vectors for diagonal networks, or low-rank matrices for matrix sensing). Establishing convergence of wÎ»superscriptğ‘¤ğœ†w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to such singular points remains an open and challenging problem, which we leave for future work.

In summary, our results capture the grokking dynamics near nonsingular points in â„³âˆ—superscriptâ„³\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, but do not yet account for potential convergence toward singular points, which represents an important open challenge.

Appendix D Additional experiments

D.1 Additional Experimental Details

In all our figures and to align with the continuous-time analysis, training iterations refers to the rescaled "training time" tk=Î³â¢ksubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ›¾ğ‘˜t_{k}=\gamma kitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î³ italic_k, where kğ‘˜kitalic_k is the number of gradient steps and Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ the gradient descent stepsize. We run gradient descent 107superscript10710^{7}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations for FigureÂ 2 and 106superscript10610^{6}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations for FigureÂ 3.

D.2 Diagonal linear networks.

Experimental setup (FigureÂ 4). We train a two-layer diagonal linear network of the form fwâ¢(x)=âŸ¨uâŠ™v,Ï†â¢(x)âŸ©subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¤ğ‘¥direct-productğ‘¢ğ‘£ğœ‘ğ‘¥f_{w}(x)=\langle u\odot v,\varphi(x)\rangleitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = âŸ¨ italic_u âŠ™ italic_v , italic_Ï† ( italic_x ) âŸ©, where w=(u,v)âˆˆâ„2â¢dğ‘¤ğ‘¢ğ‘£superscriptâ„2ğ‘‘w=(u,v)\in\mathbb{R}^{2d}italic_w = ( italic_u , italic_v ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and âŠ™direct-product\odotâŠ™ denotes element-wise multiplication, on a 1D toy dataset. The training dataset consists of n=12ğ‘›12n=12italic_n = 12 input-output pairs (xi,yi)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–(x_{i},y_{i})( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are sampled uniformly in [âˆ’1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ] and yi=fâ¢(xi)subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–y_{i}=f(x_{i})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). These training points are shown as crosses in FigureÂ 4. We optimise the squared loss Fâ¢(w)=12â¢nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’fwâ¢(xi))2ğ¹ğ‘¤12ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–2F(w)=\tfrac{1}{2n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(y_{i}-f_{w}(x_{i})\right)^{2}italic_F ( italic_w ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using gradient descent with weight decay Î»=10âˆ’4ğœ†superscript104\lambda=10^{-4}italic_Î» = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Finally, the initial weights are sampled from a centered Gaussian of variance 0.10.10.10.1.

Explaining the observed grokking phenomenon. At time t1=0subscriptğ‘¡10t_{1}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the weights are randomly initialised and the training loss is high. By t2=102subscriptğ‘¡2superscript102t_{2}=10^{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the training loss has dropped to nearly zero, and the iterates closely approximate the solution that would be obtained by unregularised gradient flow. This solution is fully characterised by the implicit regularisation result ofÂ [Woodworth etÂ al., 2020], and it does not have a low norm.444One could also reach the solution observed at time t3=105subscriptğ‘¡3superscript105t_{3}=10^{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT without using weight decay by employing a much smaller initialisation scaleÂ Woodworth etÂ al. [2020], but at the cost of longer training time. Subsequently, around time t=1/Î»ğ‘¡1ğœ†t=1/\lambdaitalic_t = 1 / italic_Î», the weight norms begin to decrease, and by t3â‰ˆ105subscriptğ‘¡3superscript105t_{3}\approx 10^{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, they converge to the minimum-norm solution (uâ‹†,vâ‹†)=argâ¡minFâ¢(u,v)=0â¡â€–uâ€–22+â€–vâ€–22superscriptğ‘¢â‹†superscriptğ‘£â‹†subscriptğ¹ğ‘¢ğ‘£0superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¢22superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘£22(u^{\star},v^{\star})=\arg\min_{F(u,v)=0}\|u\|_{2}^{2}+\|v\|_{2}^{2}( italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_u , italic_v ) = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A straightforward calculation shows that the elementwise product Î²â‹†â‰”uâ‹†âŠ™vâ‹†â‰”superscriptğ›½â‹†direct-productsuperscriptğ‘¢â‹†superscriptğ‘£â‹†\beta^{\star}\coloneqq u^{\star}\odot v^{\star}italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ™ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT solves the problem argâ¡minâŸ¨Î²,xiâŸ©=yiâ¢âˆ€iâ¡â€–Î²â€–1subscriptğ›½subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–for-allğ‘–subscriptnormğ›½1\arg\min_{\langle\beta,x_{i}\rangle=y_{i}\forall i}\|\beta\|_{1}roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ italic_Î² , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ€ italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Î² âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is an â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-minimisation problem, which (under RIP conditions) is known to recover the sparsest solutionÂ [Candes, 2008], explaining the zero test loss after the grokking phenomenon.
